Industry Overview

  • Consumer finance / NBFC segment remains a structural growth area in India driven by under-penetration, digitisation, and rising retail credit demand; NBFC leaders with scale and tech capabilities tend to capture disproportionate share of incremental retail volumes.
  • Interest-rate cycle easing and cheaper wholesale funding (visible in H1‑FY26 guidance) should support margin recovery for well‑capitalised NBFCs but will vary by funding mix and asset re-pricing speed.
  • Competitive pressure (banks + fintechs) is highest in cards, mortgages and small-ticket personal loans; incumbents win on distribution, cross-sell and underwriting data advantages.
  • Regulatory oversight has increased after recent years of NBFC expansion; capital buffers and conservative ALM/liquidity remain differentiators for investors.

Detailed Analysis & Scores

Sectoral Analysis: 8/10

Metric Value
Consolidated AUM (FY25) ₹4,16,661 Cr
Customer franchise (FY25) 101.82 Mn
Company market share (credit, approx.) ~2.14% of India’s total credit
Cost of funds (FY25) 7.97%
NIM / Financing margin Stabilising; management guides modest improvement

Score Reasoning:

  • Large addressable market: India consumer credit remains under‑penetrated and Bajaj Finance’s diversified product portfolio positions it to capture secular growth in retail, mortgage, SME and gold loans.
  • Scale & distribution edge: 100M+ customer franchise, ~4.2K locations and >200K distribution points provide durable customer acquisition advantage vs newer fintechs.
  • Interest-rate tailwind: Management expects incremental easing in cost of funds (guidance FY26); this should support modest NIM expansion if pass‑through and deployment align.
  • Competitive & regulatory intensity: Banks and fintechs pressurise pricing in mortgages/cards; regulatory scrutiny on NBFCs remains a watch item which raises execution complexity.
  • Short-term segment headwinds (MSME, some auto portfolios) temper the otherwise strong secular sector outlook.

Financial Strength: 8/10

Metric Value
CRAR (FY25) 21.9%
ROE (FY25) 19.2%
ROA (FY25) ~4.6%
PAT (FY25 consolidated) ₹16,779 Cr
Total borrowings (Mar 2025) ₹3,61,249 Cr

Score Reasoning:

  • Strong capital cushions: CRAR ~22% (Tier‑1 ~21%) gives ample buffer for growth and provisioning shocks; management flagged surplus capital post QIP/BHFL listing.
  • High profitability metrics: ROE ~19% and ROA in mid‑single digits are attractive for a large NBFC and have been delivered consistently historically.
  • Rapid, well‑funded growth: AUM grew ~26% YoY to ₹4.16 lakh Cr (FY25); growth funded by mix of borrowings, NCDs, deposits and securitisation — balance sheet expanded materially.
  • Liquidity & ALM: Liquidity buffer (mid‑FY25) ~₹14–19k Cr; LCR well above regulatory floors — provides cushion against short-term market dislocations.
  • Cashflow dynamics: Operating cash flow is negative while the company grows loan book (typical for lenders); free cash flow across the industry is negative during scaling phases — monitor funding spreads & securitisation execution.

Valuations: 6/10

Metric Value
P/E (current) 31.35
Price / Book (current) 5.64
EV / EBITDA 17.8
Median PE (12m) ~31.8

Score Reasoning:

  • Premium multiples: BAJFINANCE trades at notably higher P/E and P/B than the peer median (peer median P/E ~21.3), reflecting high ROE and growth but leaving limited margin of safety.
  • Growth premium partly justified: Strong AUM/customer growth and superior ROE underpin the premium — however any persistent credit‑cost uptick or margin pressure would compress multiples quickly.
  • Peer context: Peers trade a wide range — some (Shriram) materially cheaper on P/E; SBI Cards trades richer. Bajaj’s premium is defendable but valuation sensitivity to credit cost is high.
  • EV/EBITDA elevated vs median: Implies market prices in secular growth and operating leverage; investors must be comfortable paying for execution.
  • Balanced view: Not a deep-value case; upside depends on execution of FinAI/efficiency and re‑rating resilience.

Growth Potential: 8/10

Metric Value
AUM growth (FY25) 26% YoY
FY26 AUM guidance 24–25%
New loans booked (FY25) 43.42 Mn
Customer franchise growth (FY25) 101.82 Mn vs 83.6 Mn

Score Reasoning:

  • High organic growth: Consistent >20% AUM growth and record customer additions (14–16 Mn guidance) provide a visible growth runway.
  • Product & distribution diversification: Growth levers include mortgages (BHFL), gold loans (fast add), SME, payments & broking (BFSL), and strategic partnerships (e.g., Airtel) to widen reach.
  • FinAI (AI-first) program: Management expects AI deployment to materially improve underwriting, collections and opex — credible upside if delivery matches plan.
  • Execution risk: Growth quality matters — management’s pruning of stressed segments (2W/3W, some MSME) shows discipline but temporarily slows some volumes.
  • Medium-term upside: If credit cost normalises to guided range and NIMs stabilise/improve slightly, earnings compounding supports high EPS growth.

Key Strengths

  • Market-leading NBFC with diversified product mix and very large customer franchise (100M+).
  • Strong capitalisation (CRAR ~22%), significant liquidity buffers and multiple funding channels.
  • Scalable digital distribution (app + omnipresence) and clear FinAI programme to drive productivity and credit analytics.
  • Proven execution on growth and cross‑sell; consistent ROE and profitability track record.
  • Shareholder-friendly capital actions (dividend, bonus, BHFL listing) and zero promoter pledge.

Key Concerns

  • Elevated credit costs in FY25 / Q1 FY26 and pockets of stress in MSME and legacy 2W/3W books — key downside risk.
  • Rich absolute valuation; market is pricing high execution confidence and low downside.
  • Management transition (MD resignation) introduces temporary governance/leadership uncertainty though internal continuity was arranged.
  • Funding‑mix sensitivity: reliance on market borrowings and NCDs makes earnings sensitive to funding spreads.
  • Large negative operating cashflow while balance sheet scales — typical for lenders but requires continued market access.

Scenario Analysis

Optimistic Scenario

Target Price: ₹1,250 (12 months)
Key Drivers: Faster-than-expected normalisation of credit costs (credit cost falls to <1.6% AUF), 25%+ AUM growth, NIM expansion of 10–20 bps from funding mix improvement, and multiple expansion (P/E moves toward 36–38) as AI efficiency gains and BHFL listing unlock ROE upside.

Realistic Scenario

Target Price: ₹1,050 (12 months)
Key Drivers: Management guides AUM growth 24–25% and credit cost 1.85–1.95% FY26; EPS growth ~15–18% (from TTM EPS ~28 to ~33) and market assigns a stable multiple near historical median (P/E ~31–32), yielding ~20% price upside.

Pessimistic Scenario

Target Price: ₹700 (12 months)
Key Drivers: Broader macro slowdown and a renewed deterioration in MSME/auto vintages increases credit cost materially (>2.2% AUF), margin compression and multiple contraction to P/E ~20–22 or P/B compression to ~4x produce ~‑20% downside.

Investment Recommendation Based on Target Analysis:

  • Primary Recommendation: BUY — realistic-case shows ~20% upside vs current price (≥15% threshold for BUY).

Recommendation Reasoning:

  • High-quality franchise with strong scale, diversified product mix, and durable cross‑sell gives high probability of earnings compounding.
  • Management has credible plans (FinAI, deposits mix, pruning risky segments) to bring credit costs within guided band and improve operating efficiency.
  • Current valuation already prices growth but realistic scenario shows meaningful upside (~20%) — hence BUY with entry discipline.
  • Key watch-items: execution on AI, credit‑cost trajectory (early‑vintage performance), leadership continuity and funding spreads.

Investment Thesis

  1. Durable franchise economics: Bajaj Finance’s large customer base, high cross-sell potential and diversified AUM mix underpin high ROE and earnings visibility.
  2. Growth with prudence: Management targets 24–25% AUM growth for FY26 while pruning higher-risk pockets — growth is strong and increasingly driven by newer, secured products.
  3. Margin & cost upside available via funding mix and FinAI: modest NIM uptick plus expected OPEX/NTI improvement (40–50 bps) should enhance medium‑term profitability.
  4. Capital & liquidity strength: CRAR ~22% and sizeable liquidity buffers reduce tail‑risk and support sustained growth even under stress.
  5. Valuation requires execution: Market prices premium multiples — positive risk‑reward if management executes on credit normalisation and AI benefits; otherwise valuation is vulnerable.
